q: Nokia will fold its own app store into the Microsoft Marketplace. Stephen Elop the optimist In a press conference today, Stephen Elop and Steve Ballmer touted the alliance as good for both companies' aspirations. A pessimist sees the difficulty in every opportunity, but an optimist sees the opportunity in every difficulty, Stephen Elop said, quoting England's historic prime minister Winston Churchill as he spoke in London. While Philadelphia remained Scottie Pippen 1/2 games behind Boston in the Atlantic Division, Chris Webber gave a glimpse of what he could contribute down the stretch. "I think every little bit helps your confidence," Chris Webber said. One day you're averaging a number that many people don't do in three categories and the next day you're worthless. And that's from myself, I don't even care what everyone else is saying. Allen Iverson , who had nine assists, knew Chris Webber was trying too hard to meet monstrous expectations. Stephen Elop -- a former Microsoft executive-- chose Windows over Android. Nokia will contribute its mapping technology to Microsoft's Bing search engine-- and integrate its application and content store into the Microsoft Marketplace. Nokia also will contribute its expertise on hardware design, language support, and help bring Windows Phone to a larger range of price points, market segments and geographies, according to a Microsoft news release. "The partnership announced today provides incredible scale, vast expertise in hardware and software innovation and a proven ability to execute," Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer said in the statement
